How to Play \n

To play the game, one of the participants will have to demonstrate basic musical skills.

The game is designed to work alone or in a clinical setting. When working with a client, the therapist should allow them the autonomy to choose any card to begin with, and engage in the songwriting process along the way.

To begin: Separate the cards into the following groups according to the label on the front of each card: \n Theme, Melody, Lyric, Instruments & Chord Progression

Procedure \n

Pick any card to start the songwriting process. After implementing the rules presented on that card, you may pick another card to continue the process.

The song is complete once you include all five songwriting elements within your cards. If you feel the need to continue your song with more sections (a bridge, a new verse, chorus), simply continue drawing cards to inspire you along your creative process.

Note: Feel free to develop your song beyond the cards that are presented to you, these are just starting points.

About The Cards\n

Theme: This will typically be the starting point in the songwriting process to set up the mood and theme for the song. However, if you already have a theme in mind, you may skip them.

Lyric: Follow the directions on each card.

Chord Progression: Follow the chord progression presented on each card.

As a variation: You may also choose two cards: one card will address the chord progression of the verse, while the other card may be used as the chord progression of the chorus.

Instruments: Play the instrument presented on the card while singing your song.

Variations:

1) You may add that instrument as an embellishment throughout the song.

2) You may choose two cards, one instrument to be played during the verse, and the other during the chorus.

Melody: Follow the directions on each card on how to come up and develop a motive Keep in mind: Each card guides you through developing only the first 4 measures, you may draw total of 3 cards to create a complete 12 measure verse or course.\n Note: Eventually, you will have to adjust the melody to the chord progression and the key of the song.
